greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of proper divisors of n of the form 6*k + 3.
comment: Number of divisors of n that are odd multiples of 3 and less than n.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
formula: G.f.: Sum_{k>=1} x^(12*k-6) / (1 - x^(6*k-3)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 14 2021
example: For n = 18, of its five proper divisors [1, 2, 3, 6, 9] only 3 and 9 are odd multiples of three, thus a(18) = 2.
For n = 108, the odd part is 27 for which 27/3 has 3 divisors. As 108 is even, we don't subtract 1 from that 3 to get a(108) = 3. - _David A. Corneth_, Oct 03 2018
program: (PARI) a(n) = if(n%3==0, my(v=valuation(n, 2)); n>>=v; numdiv(n/3)-(!v), 0) \\ _David A. Corneth_, Oct 03 2018
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 03 2018
